title: Potion of sickness
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Potion_of_sickness/zh-CN "Potion of sickness/zh-CN")

| ! [![Pink potion.png](/images/7/79/Pink_potion.png)](/wiki/File:Pink_potion.png) |                                                               |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                             | sickness                                                      |
| Appearance                                                                       | [random](/wiki/Randomised_appearance "Randomised appearance") |
| Base price                                                                       | 50 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")                              |
| Weight                                                                           | 20                                                            |
| Monster use                                                                      | *Will not be used by monsters.*                               |

A **potion of sickness** is a type of [potion](/wiki/Potion "Potion") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
  - [1.1 Alchemy](#Alchemy)

- [2 Description](#Description)

  - [2.1 Dipping](#Dipping)
  - [2.2 Throwing and wielding](#Throwing_and_wielding)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [3.1 Identification](#Identification)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

[Rogues](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue") start the game with an uncursed potion of sickness.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Pestilence](/wiki/Pestilence "Pestilence") will always generate with a stack of several potions of sickness.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [charged](/wiki/Charge "Charge") [horn of plenty](/wiki/Horn_of_plenty "Horn of plenty") has a 0.3% chance of generating a potion of sickness.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

### Alchemy

When performing [alchemy](/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy") by mixing two random types of potion that have no recipe, and the dipped stack of potions is not diluted, the result is a stack of potions of sickness 22.5% of the time.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) Dipping a stack of [fruit juice](/wiki/Fruit_juice "Fruit juice") potions into a potion of sickness will 'contaminate' the stack, turning them into potions of sickness. Dipping a potion(s) of [healing](/wiki/Potion_of_healing "Potion of healing"), [extra healing](/wiki/Potion_of_extra_healing "Potion of extra healing"), or [full healing](/wiki/Potion_of_full_healing "Potion of full healing") into a potion of sickness will turn them into potions of fruit juice.

## Description

As indicated by alchemy and some of [the messages](#Messages) associated with it, the potion of sickness is biologically contaminated fruit juice, and those messages use [the name of that fruit](/wiki/Nameable_fruit "Nameable fruit") when printed.

[Quaffing](/wiki/Quaff "Quaff") a potion of sickness will cause the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") to lose HP, lower one of their attributes and possibly abuse [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution"), depending on beatitude and whether or not they have [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance")[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) - it does *not* cause terminal [sickness](/wiki/Sickness "Sickness") (e.g. as with food poisoning). A hero with the [sustain ability](/wiki/Sustain_ability "Sustain ability") property does not suffer attribute loss.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

A [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer") is completely protected from the above effects when quaffing the potion.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) Quaffing the potion will also shock the hero out of [hallucination](/wiki/Hallucination "Hallucination") and back to their senses.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

The effects of beatitude on the potion are displayed below:

| Case     | You have no poison resistance                                                           | You have poison resistance                                                        |
| -------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| blessed  | You lose 1 hit point.                                                                   | You lose 1 hit point.                                                             |
| uncursed | You lose 1-10 hit points, one of your attributes is reduced by 3-6, abuse constitution. | You lose 1 hit point, one of your attributes is reduced by 1, abuse constitution. |
| cursed   | You lose 1-15 hit points, one of your attributes is reduced by 3-6, abuse constitution. | You lose 1 hit point, one of your attributes is reduced by 1, abuse constitution. |

While monsters do not quaff or otherwise use potions of sickness, Pestilence will quaff potions of sickness to heal himself like other monsters would with a [potion of healing](/wiki/Potion_of_healing "Potion of healing"); hitting Pestilence with the potion will have the same effect.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

Inhaling the [vapors](/wiki/Vapor "Vapor") of a thrown, boiled or smashed potion causes the hero to lose 5 HP regardless of beatitude or poison resistance, or else sets their HP to 1 if they currently have less than 5, and abuses constitution; the vapors have no effect on a Healer.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

### Dipping

If you #[dip](/wiki/Dip "Dip") a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") into the potion, it will become a potion of fruit juice - this also happens if you [cancel](/wiki/Cancel "Cancel") the potion.

If you dip [darts](/wiki/Dart "Dart"), [arrows](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow"), [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken"), or [crossbow bolts](/wiki/Crossbow_bolt "Crossbow bolt") into a potion of sickness, it will coat the stack of projectiles in [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison"), using up the potion and prompting you to type-[name](/wiki/Name "Name") it if unidentified. Poisoned weapons do d6 extra damage and have a 1⁄10 chance of instantly killing non-resistant monsters;[\[13\]](#cite_note-13) the poison has a 1⁄10 chance of wearing off on each successful attack.[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)

### Throwing and wielding

Hitting a monster with a [wielded](/wiki/Wielded "Wielded") or [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") potion will reduce their hit points if successful: monsters with a sickness attack or poison resistance are immune, while other monsters have their current HP and maximum HP halved, each subject to separate rolls versus [monster MR](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)"). if the monster's maximum HP is brought below the current HP, the current HP is reduced to the new maximum HP.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As of [commit 43f42b35](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/43f42b35e6eb76254631f1369cd5725bad4fbc4f), the effect of hitting a monster with a potion of sickness no longer depends on monster MR, but halves only the current HP of monsters without poison resistance.

## Strategy

Potions of sickness are typically best used for poisoning projectiles, though [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") characters will take a -1 hit to their [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") for each use of a poisoned weapon; alchemy makes it somewhat easy to procure more potions for poisoning projectiles with. There are many late-game monsters, up to and including some otherwise-powerful [quest nemeses](/wiki/Quest_nemeses "Quest nemeses"), that lack poison resistance and can be easily felled by something as simple as a stack of poisoned projectiles; [Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") in particular that hold on to their starting stack of +2 darts can poison them to use as an effective weapon against the [Master of Thieves](/wiki/Master_of_Thieves "Master of Thieves").

While a potion of sickness can be used as a hallucination cure if you can mitigate the HP and attribute loss (e.g. with poison resistance, a [potion of restore ability](/wiki/Potion_of_restore_ability "Potion of restore ability"), or a [ring of sustain ability](/wiki/Ring_of_sustain_ability "Ring of sustain ability")), they are only worth using for this purpose if you lack any other cure, such as potions of [extra healing](/wiki/Potion_of_extra_healing "Potion of extra healing"), [full healing](/wiki/Potion_of_full_healing "Potion of full healing") or a unicorn horn.

For players that have no interest in poisoned weapons, this potion is a good candidate for [dilution](/wiki/Dilution "Dilution") or else converting to fruit juice for other purposes.

### Identification

The potion of sickness is one of four 50[zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm") potions, along with the potions of fruit juice, [see invisible](/wiki/Potion_of_see_invisible "Potion of see invisible") and [booze](/wiki/Potion_of_booze "Potion of booze") - incidentally, all of the other potions can be made from fruit juice.

Potions of sickness can be easily identified by dip-testing with a unicorn horn, as discussed above; while cancelling them also turns them into fruit juice, cancelling the [potion of see invisible](/wiki/Potion_of_see_invisible "Potion of see invisible") has the same effect. Dipping a non-poisoned [missile](/wiki/Missile "Missile") weapon into a potion of sickness will form a coating on it, which is reliable for informal identification.

## History

The potion of sickness first appears in Hack for PDP-11, a variant of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"); Hack 1.21, another variant, has a somewhat-similar potion of poison.

In versions prior to [NetHack 3.6.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.3 "NetHack 3.6.3"), the case for dipping healing potions fell through to the unicorn horn case due to a missing `break` statement, causing the combination of healing and sickness to alchemize to fruit juice, and the combination of healing and hallucination, blindness, or confusion to alchemize to water.[\[15\]](#cite_note-15)[\[16\]](#cite_note-16) This behavior was made explicit and intentional in NetHack 3.6.3 via [commit c6b75407](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/c6b7540712edfde8495bd3a41b018aa0d8a1eecc).

## Messages

- Yecch! This stuff tastes like poison.

  You quaffed a potion of sickness.

- (But in fact it was mildly stale <[slime mold](/wiki/Slime_mold "Slime mold")> juice.)

  This line is added if the potion was blessed.

- (But in fact it was biologically contaminated <[slime mold](/wiki/Slime_mold "Slime mold")> juice.)

  This line is added if you quaffed a non-blessed potion and have poison resistance; you only lose one attribute point.

- Fortunately, you have been immunized.

  You are a [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), so you suffer no ill effects.

- You are shocked back to your senses!

  You were hallucinating, and were cured by quaffing the potion.

* You feel weaker.

  Your [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") was lowered.

* Your muscles won't obey you.

  Your [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") was lowered.

* You feel very sick.

  Your [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") was lowered.

* Your brain is on fire.

  Your [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") was lowered.

* Your judgement is impaired.

  Your [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") was lowered.

* You break out in hives.

  Your [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") was lowered.

- \<monster> looks rather ill.

  A monster without immunity was hit by a potion of sickness, or [Pestilence](/wiki/Pestilence "Pestilence") was hit by a [potion of healing](/wiki/Potion_of_healing "Potion of healing").

- \<monster> looks unharmed.

  A monster with a sickness attack or poison resistance was hit by a potion of sickness.

- \<potion> forms a coating on \<item>.

  You dipped a poisonable item into a potion of sickness.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), bladed weapons can be poisoned as well using a potion of sickness, and poisoned weapons are also subject to a [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight")-based chance of losing their poisonous coating (1 in \[10 - (weight/10)] chance).

The Chamber of Junk in the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest") has a 2⁄5 chance of containing two cursed potions of sickness.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") also allows bladed weapons to be poisoned using a potion of sickness.
